history.content:
I think taking 161 without 61C under your belt would be extremely difficult, especially in the beginning of the semester. I tried doing this this semester and ended up dropping 161. Unlike some of the other CS upperdivs, I'd say 61C is pretty much a hard pre-req for 161.

However tho, if you already have experience dealing with C and low-level CS/systems, then there shouldn't be much stopping you..

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

As someone who took 61c last semester and is currently taking 161, I would mostly agree with the idea that 161 would be extremely difficult without 61c, although I would say that this mostly applies to the first section of the course, which deals with C code. However, also getting used to working with bits, memory, and other concepts that are not as frequently dealt with in the other cs61 courses is another huge reason why 61c is a huge help for 161 in general, not just the first part of the course.

I think taking 161 without 61C under your belt would be extremely difficult, especially in the beginning of the semester. I tried doing this this semester and ended up dropping 161. Unlike some of the other CS upperdivs, I'd say 61C is pretty much a hard pre-req for 161.

However tho, if you already have experience dealing with C and low-level CS/systems, then there shouldn't be much stopping you..
I'm wondering how feasible the above schedule is in terms of workload next semester, possibly alongside a breadth class.
history.subject: CS61C + EE16A + CS161
